description: Initial prime in first sequence of n primes congruent to 1 modulo 6.
references: R. K. Guy, "Unsolved Problems in Number Theory", A4
links: Giovanni Resta, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..35 (terms < 4*10^14)
example: a(6) = 1741 because this number is the first in a sequence of 6 consecutive primes all of the form 3n + 1.
mathematica: NextPrime[ n_Integer ] := Module[ {k = n + 1}, While[ ! PrimeQ[ k ], k++ ]; Return[ k ]]; PrevPrime[ n_Integer ] := Module[ {k = n - 1}, While[ ! PrimeQ[ k ], k-- ]; Return[ k ]]; p = 0; Do[ a = Table[ -1, {n} ]; k = Max[ 1, p ]; While[ Union[ a ] != {1}, k = NextPrime[ k ]; a = Take[ AppendTo[ a, Mod[ k, 3 ]], -n ]]; p = NestList[ PrevPrime, k, n ]; Print[ p[[ -2 ] ]]; p = p[[ -1 ]], {n, 1, 18} ]
